<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 291, 539, 321]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 571, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 729, 865]]<|/det|>
This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 808, 91]]<|/det|>
Two forces with magnitudes \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\) act on an object at right angles to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 489, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the resultant force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 129, 737, 152]]<|/det|>
\(\sqrt{F_1^2 + F_2^2}\) <label>B</label> \(\sqrt{F_1} + \sqrt{F_2}\) <label>C</label> \(\sqrt{F_1^2} + \sqrt{F_2^2}\) <label>D</label> \(\sqrt{F_1} + F_2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 183, 97, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 920, 217]]<|/det|>
A boy takes 30 minutes to cycle a distance of \(8.0 \text{km}\). He then walks a further distance of \(2.0 \text{km}\) in 15 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 348, 247]]<|/det|>
What is his average speed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 256, 133, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 256, 230, 275]]<|/det|>
4.5km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 256, 298, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 256, 398, 275]]<|/det|>
5.6km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 256, 468, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 256, 560, 275]]<|/det|>
12km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 256, 636, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 256, 727, 275]]<|/det|>
13km/h

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 301, 97, 320]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|> Three liquids P, Q and R have different densities and do not mix. The liquids are placed in a measuring cylinder and allowed to settle. A small block is then dropped into the measuring cylinder and comes to rest, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 127, 625, 297]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 308, 594, 327]]<|/det|> Which statement about the density of the block is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 337, 134, 355]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 336, 393, 355]]<|/det|> It is equal to the density of Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 134, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 362, 425, 380]]<|/det|> It is greater than the density of P. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 134, 407]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 388, 425, 407]]<|/det|> It is greater than the density of R. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 415, 134, 433]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 415, 403, 433]]<|/det|> It is less than the density of Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 458, 96, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 458, 586, 477]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a uniform beam pivoted at its centre. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 489, 534, 507]]<|/det|> A student applies two forces, \(F_{1}\) and \(F_{2}\), as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 515, 670, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 297, 679]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 484, 853]]<|/det|>
clockwise moment about the pivotanticlockwise moment about the pivot
A\(F_{2}d_{2}\)\(F_{1}d_{1}\)
B\(F_{2}d_{2}\)\(F_{1}d_{3}\)
C\(F_{2}d_{4}\)\(F_{1}d_{1}\)
D\(F_{2}d_{4}\)\(F_{1}d_{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 720, 89]]<|/det|> Which expression can be used to determine the impulse on a tennis ball? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 136, 118]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 101, 253, 118]]<|/det|> force \(\times\) time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 135, 134, 153]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 131, 250, 149]]<|/det|> momentum <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 148, 222, 165]]<|/det|> time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 134, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 176, 331, 193]]<|/det|> mass \(\times\) initial velocity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 203, 134, 221]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 203, 319, 220]]<|/det|> mass \(\times\) acceleration <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 248, 96, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 247, 920, 280]]<|/det|> Which row shows the process by which energy in the Sun is released, the process by which it is transferred to the Earth and a way in which it is stored once it reaches the Earth? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 803, 454]]<|/det|>

This cube contains the same mass of the same gas as the first cube, at the same temperature. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 255, 625, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 446, 547, 465]]<|/det|> What is the pressure of the gas in the second cube? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 473, 133, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 473, 761, 492]]<|/det|> 1000 N/ m² B 4000 N/ m² C 16 000 N/ m² D 64 000 N/ m² <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 520, 106, 538]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 672, 539]]<|/det|> Which row gives the correct name for each change of state shown? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 599, 680]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 706, 106, 725]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 706, 920, 740]]<|/det|> In an experiment to measure specific heat capacity, a block of aluminium is heated and its rise in temperature is measured. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 752, 920, 786]]<|/det|> The internal energy gained by the block is \(\Delta E\). The mass of the block is \(m\). The rise in temperature of the block is \(\Delta T\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 797, 648, 816]]<|/det|> Which expression gives the specific heat capacity of aluminium? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 134, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 828, 210, 848]]<|/det|> \(\frac{m}{\Delta E\Delta T}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 828, 303, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 828, 371, 848]]<|/det|> \(\frac{m\Delta T}{\Delta E}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 828, 470, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 828, 537, 848]]<|/det|> \(\frac{\Delta E}{m\Delta T}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 828, 636, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 828, 715, 848]]<|/det|> \(\frac{\Delta E\Delta T}{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 648, 89]]<|/det|> Which statement about the transfer of thermal energy is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 539, 118]]<|/det|> All metals conduct thermal energy equally well. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 125, 529, 144]]<|/det|> Convection can only occur in solids or liquids. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 131, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 151, 794, 170]]<|/det|> Convection occurs in liquids because hot liquid is more dense than cold liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 177, 818, 196]]<|/det|> The radiation that transfers thermal energy is a type of electromagnetic radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 222, 107, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 688, 241]]<|/det|> What is the number of wavefronts per second that pass a fixed point? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 133, 269]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 252, 368, 269]]<|/det|> the amplitude of the wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 279, 133, 297]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 279, 368, 297]]<|/det|> the frequency of the wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 306, 133, 324]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 304, 336, 322]]<|/det|> the speed of the wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 331, 133, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 331, 378, 349]]<|/det|> the wavelength of the wave <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 373, 106, 392]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 838, 392]]<|/det|> An earthquake under the ocean can produce a dangerous water wave called a tsunami. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 404, 462, 422]]<|/det|> The table gives typical data for a tsunami. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 433, 685, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 279, 445, 298]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 306, 631, 465]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 477, 348, 496]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 505, 134, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 505, 564, 526]]<|/det|>
The current reading on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_{1}\) is the highest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 532, 134, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 532, 564, 551]]<|/det|>
The current reading on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_{2}\) is the highest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 131, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 559, 564, 578]]<|/det|>
The current reading on ammeter \(\mathsf{A}_{3}\) is the highest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 585, 133, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 585, 742, 604]]<|/det|>
The current readings on all three ammeters \(\mathsf{A}_{1}, \mathsf{A}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{A}_{3}\) are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 693, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an arrangement of resistors in series and parallel.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 101, 625, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 752, 273]]<|/det|>
Which equation is used to calculate the combined resistance of the resistors?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 291, 134, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 262, 320]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} + \frac{R_{2} + R_{3}}{R_{2}\times R_{3}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 330, 262, 368]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} + \frac{R_{2}\times R_{3}}{R_{2} + R_{3}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 134, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 381, 262, 416]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1} + \frac{1}{R_{2} + R_{3}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 438, 134, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 431, 262, 470]]<|/det|>
\[R_{1}\times \frac{R_{2} + R_{3}}{R_{2}\times R_{3}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 104, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 640, 518]]<|/det|>
An electrical engineer has made a pair of components P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
The resistance of P decreases as the temperature rises. The resistance of Q increases as the temperature rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
The total resistance of P and Q in series remains constant when the temperature changes. The two components are connected in series with a power source supplying a constant current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 621, 348, 638]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 650, 134, 667]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 648, 920, 682]]<|/det|>
If a temperature change causes the potential difference (p.d.) across P to double, the p.d. across Q will always halve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 134, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
The difference between the p.d. across P and the p.d. across Q does not change with temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 131, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 731, 692, 749]]<|/det|>
The p.d. across component P increases as the temperature rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 757, 133, 775]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 757, 865, 775]]<|/det|>
The sum of the p.d. across P and the p.d. across Q does not change with temperature.

induced current		direction of
the force

into the page

towards the top of the page

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 392, 106, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 609, 410]]<|/det|>
An \(\alpha\) -particle and a \(\beta\) -particle have the same kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 910, 441]]<|/det|>
Why does the \(\alpha\) -particle have a larger ionising effect than the \(\beta\) -particle as it passes through air?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 133, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 452, 920, 486]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particle has a larger charge and a larger velocity so is closer to an air particle for a shorter time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particle has a larger charge and a smaller velocity so is closer to an air particle for a longer time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 133, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particle has a smaller charge and a larger velocity so is closer to an air particle for a shorter time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 133, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
The \(\alpha\) -particle has a smaller charge and a smaller velocity so is closer to an air particle for a longer time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 865, 89]]<|/det|> A student is carrying out an experiment to measure the radiation from a radioactive source. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 134]]<|/det|> He uses a radiation detector and records the total counts in 5-minute intervals. He does this three times with the source present and three times with the source absent. Here are his results. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 147, 692, 282]]<|/det|>
total counts in
5 minutes
with source present		total counts in
5 minutes
with source absent
6825
7328
6922
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 295, 584, 312]]<|/det|> What is the average corrected count rate for the source? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 324, 134, 342]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 324, 292, 342]]<|/det|> 5 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 351, 134, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 351, 292, 368]]<|/det|> 9 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 134, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 377, 302, 394]]<|/det|> 25 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 134, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 402, 302, 420]]<|/det|> 45 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 446, 106, 465]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 446, 920, 495]]<|/det|> The count rate measured near a radioactive source drops from 542 counts per minute to 94 counts per minute in 12 hours. The background count remains constant at 30 counts per minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 507, 400, 524]]<|/det|> What is the half-life of the source? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 133, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 535, 218, 553]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 535, 303, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 535, 388, 553]]<|/det|> 3 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 535, 470, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 535, 551, 553]]<|/det|> 4 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 535, 636, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 535, 718, 553]]<|/det|> 8 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 580, 107, 598]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 579, 598]]<|/det|> What happens when a protostar becomes a stable star? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 609, 134, 626]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 609, 740, 626]]<|/det|> Most of the hydrogen is converted to helium and the protostar expands. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 635, 133, 653]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 635, 915, 653]]<|/det|> The inward force due to gravity is balanced by an outward force due to the high temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 134, 679]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 661, 725, 679]]<|/det|> The protostar collapses due to gravity and the temperature increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 134, 705]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 688, 700, 705]]<|/det|> The protostar runs out of hydrogen as fuel for the nuclear reaction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 732, 89]]<|/det|> The table gives information about some of the planets in our Solar System. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 100, 888, 247]]<|/det|>
planetmass compared with the Earthaverage density
g/cm³		gravitational field strength at surface
N / kg
Earth1.05.59.8
Jupiter3201.325
Mercury0.0605.43.8
Uranus151.310
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 259, 515, 277]]<|/det|> Which statement about these planets is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 286, 134, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 286, 809, 304]]<|/det|> As the mass compared with the Earth increases, the average density increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 313, 131, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 313, 888, 331]]<|/det|> As the mass compared with the Earth increases, the gravitational field strength increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 339, 131, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 777, 357]]<|/det|> As the average density increases, the gravitational field strength decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 364, 131, 383]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 364, 781, 383]]<|/det|> The average density is directly proportional to the gravitational field strength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 409, 106, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 589, 428]]<|/det|> Which quantity is an estimate of the age of the Universe? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 441, 133, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 441, 176, 460]]<|/det|> \(H_0\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 439, 306, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[318, 439, 376, 460]]<|/det|> \(\mathrm{d}\times H_0\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 437, 470, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 437, 520, 470]]<|/det|> \[\frac{1}{H_0}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 440, 636, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 440, 707, 460]]<|/det|> \[\mathrm{v}\times H_0\]

This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 916, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of Cambridge Assessment. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is a department of the University of Cambridge.
